One-pot synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol using three-dimensional mesoporous silicates of K/TUD-1 under environmentally benign conditions Shivali Arora Vijayalakshmi Gosu Verraboina Subbaramaiah * Department of Chemical Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology Jaipur, 302017, India Department of Chemical Engineering Malaviya National Institute of Technology Jaipur 302017 India aDepartment of Chemical Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology Jaipur, 302017, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the present study, a series of potassium (K) incorporated three-dimensional mesoporous silica material (K/TUD-1) has been synthesized for the one-pot synthesis of glycerol carbonate through transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The synthesized catalyst (K/TUD-1) has been characterized to confirm porosity by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Small-angle XRD revealed that TUD-1 is mesostructure in nature. Morphology study revealed that TUD-1 exhibited a 3D structure without any agglomeration. The surface area of bare TUD-1 significantly declined with the incorporation of active metal from 632 m2/g to 430 m2/g. However, the basicity of K/TUD-1 improved, which is a highly desired property for the transesterification reaction. Batch experimental results have been concluded that 7% K/TUD-1 has better catalytic activity for the conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate. Further investigation has been conducted on the influence of reaction parameters such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst dosage, and DMC/glycerol molar ratio. Under optimized conditions the maximum glycerol carbonate yield (∼91.50 %) was observed with catalyst dose of 6 wt.% (of glycerol mass), DMC/glycerol molar ratio of 5, reaction temperature of 90 °C in 2.5 h. Further, catalyst feasibility was also conducted at optimized conditions, and it sustains activity up to 4 cycles. The kinetics of the reaction was studied using the ODE 15 s solver in MATLAB. Keywords Glycerol Carbonate Transesterification Glycerol TUD-1 MATLAB 1 Introduction Recently, renewable energy resources exploration has been escalated as an alternative energy source to minimize the stress on non-renewable resources. Among the many possible resources, biodiesel got much attention due to its low carbon footprint and comparable calorific value to petrol diesel. It is a fatty acids methyl ester obtained from the transesterification of free fatty acids or triglyceride with alcohols. Globally, it projected that the biodiesel contribution extent up to 4.2 × 1010 L by the year 2020 [1,2]. However, the biodiesel industry encountering a challenging problem on profitability margin due to the low market value of its by-product, glycerol. Therefore, valorization of by-product, glycerol highly needed to maximize the profit margin due to its surplus six-fold excess availability than the actual demand. Thus, it is an urgent need to valorize the glycerol to high-value-added chemicals such as glycidol, 1,3-propanediol, propanol, glycerol carbonate, etc. [3]. Among all the derivatives of glycerol, glycerol carbonate had received significant attention which possess high boiling point, good biodegradability, low toxicity, high density, low melting point, high flash point, high chemical reactivity and low evaporation rate [4,5]. Glycerol carbonate can be used as chemical intermediate for the preparation of glycidol, solvent and electrolyte for lithium ion batteries, etc. [4]. Glycerol carbonate could be prepared by the reaction of glycerol with carbon monoxide or phosgene as a carbonating source but the toxicity issues related with them limits the process industrially. The reaction of glycerol with CO2 to produce glycerol carbonate is thermodynamically limited. The utilization of urea as a carbonating source requires removal of ammonia from the reactor. Among all the conversion routes of glycerol discussed in the open literature, one-step-one-pot catalytic-transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate using dimethyl carbonate is considered to be environmentally benign processes due to its high yield and selectivity under mild operating conditions [4]. Such favorable condition may quickly help the batch scale results in industrial-scale production. The present manuscript focused on the development of a green process for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol. Many authors investigated the various homogeneous catalysts for the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) into glycerol carbonate. Despite the high catalytic activity of the homogeneous catalyst, it has the serious drawback that includes challenging to separate from the product as well as corrosion/scaling issues [1]. Due to forementioned disadvantages, heterogeneous catalysts have been engrossed in the transesterification of glycerol. The heterogeneous catalyst including calcined dolomite [6], Sr-Al mixed oxide [7], CaAl-layered double hydroxides [8], CeO2-CdO [4] have been used for the glycerol transesterification reaction. Hu et al. [9] investigated the catalytic activity of KNO3 on CaO for the transesterification of glycerol with DMC, and the test results revealed that approximately 95 % glycerol conversion was maintained even after five runs, the obtained results much higher than that of pure CaO or KNO3. Besides, many authors reported that KOH or KNO3 species proved to be a potential catalyst for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate. Regardless of providing the admirable performance towards the conversion of glycerol into glycerol carbonate, these catalysts have certain limitations such as a high rate of deactivation/low activity during recycling [10]. The available literature strongly suggests that basic sites of the stable catalyst highly desired for transesterification of glycerol. Therefore, an exploration of the novel catalyst highly required that may provide high surface area and steady catalytic activity. Recently active metal atoms incorporated mesoporous silica such as MCM-41, SBA-15, TUD-1 opened a new window in the field of catalysis. The advantage of these mesoporous materials over microporous counterpart material (such as zeolites) lies in the large pore size that provides easy accessibility of reactant species to the active sites, which is particularly essential for the reaction of larger reactant/viscous molecules such as glycerol. Devi et al. [10] explored the Ti-SBA-15 mesoporous catalyst feasibility, and the prepared catalyst exhibited a ∼100 % conversion of glycerol at 87.5 °C. However, the scare reports are available on metal oxide incorporated mesoporous catalyst for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate. In the present manuscript author synthesized the active metal (with different loading amount potassium) incorporated TUD-1 for catalytic transesterification reaction of glycerol with DMC. To the best of the author’s knowledge, none of the authors has been investigated in literature for the transesterification of the glycerol into glycerol carbonate employing K/TUD-1 as a heterogeneous catalyst. The properties of prepared catalyst have been characterized with Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Hammett titration method. Optimization of influencing parameters such as loading amount of active metal on TUD-1, DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio, catalyst dose, reaction temperature, and reaction time to maximize the turn over frequency (TOF), glycerol conversion, yield and selectivity of glycerol carbonate. The reusability of the catalyst has been studied under optimized conditions. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) model was adopted to develop the kinetic model of the reaction. The equilibrium constants of adsorption of reactants and desorption of glycerol carbonate and methanol were determined using ODE 15 s solver in MATLAB and also evaluated the activation energy of the reaction. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Material All the solvents and reagents used in this study were of analytic grade and used without any further purification. Glycerol (≥ 99 %), methanol (≥ 99 %), phenolphthalein, tetraethylammonium hydroxide solution (TEAOH; 35 wt.%), Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) and 2,4-dinitroaniline were purchased from Fisher Scientific, Mumbai, India. DMC (≥98 %) and potassium nitrate were acquired from Loba Chemie, Mumbai, India. 4-nitroaniline was obtained from Chemical Drug House (CDH) Pvt. Ltd., New Delhi, India. Ethanol was purchased from Merck, India. Triethanolamine (TEA; 97 %) was acquired from Avra Chemicals, Hyderabad, India. The standards used for calibration are stated as: glycerol carbonate (>99.0 %) was acquired from TCI Chemical Pvt. Ltd. India, pyridine (>99.99 %), and glycerol (>99.5 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, India. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The one-pot sol-gel method had been adopted for the synthesis of active metal incorporated three-dimensional mesoporous silica material (TUD-1) [11]. Triethanolamine (TEA) was used as a chelating and templating agent. The final templates have been removed using two different methods i.e., hydrothermal calcination technique and solvent extraction technique. The typical catalyst preparation procedure consists of aging, drying, and templates elimination (calcination/solvent extraction) to obtain K/TUD-1 with the molar composition of 1 Si: (0.01−0.1) M: 0.5 TEAOH: 1 TEA: 11 H2O (where M represents the molar mass of potassium). In a typical procedure, firstly, the desired molar composition of potassium nitrate (potassium precursor) mixed with distilled water to get uniform solution followed by drop-wise addition of the potassium nitrate solution into 10.80 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica source and vigorously stirred for 30 min. Simultaneously, a separate solution of 7.78 g of TEA and water was prepared, and added drop-wise into previously prepared solution with continuous stirring for one hour. After that 10.90 g of TEAOH was added drop-wise and the solution was kept under constant stirring for at least two hours until a clear liquid was obtained. Then, the obtained gel has been aged for 24 h at 30 °C followed by placing it into hot air oven at 110 °C for 24 h. Thereafter, the obtained material was transferred into teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave to undergo thermal treatment for four hours at 180 °C. Finally, the templates were removed to make a mesoporous structured three-dimensional silica framework. In the calcination method: the solid powder was calcined in air at 600 °C for ten hours with a heating rate of 1 °C/min, and designated as Cal/K-TUD-1. Similarly, in the solvent extraction technique: the template of formed powder (TUD-1) was extracted with ethanol in the Soxhlet apparatus. Typically, 2 g of solid sample was mixed with 50 mL of ethanol and then stirred for 24 h at 100 °C. The obtained catalyst was designated as Ext/K-TUD-1. A series of the catalyst has been prepared with varying loading amount of active species and named as ‘X%’ Cal/K-TUD-1 (where X represents the weight percentage of potassium). 2.3 Characterization Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra have been used to determine the functional groups present on the catalyst surface. The spectra were recorded in the region of 400−4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 2 cm−1 on PerkinElmer FTIR Spectroscopy (Massachusetts, US) using KBr pellet technique. The surface morphology of the catalyst was analyzed on Nova Nano SEM-450 FEI (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Massachusetts, US) at an accelerating voltage of 40 kV. The conductivity of the catalyst surface was enhanced by a gold sputter coating under vacuum (Q150 T ES, Quorum Technologies Ltd, Sussex, U.K). The crystallinity of the catalyst was determined by X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical X’Pert Pro, B.V., Netherlands), using Cu-Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. Wide-angle XRD scattering was recorded at a scanning rate of 2θ = 1° per min over a range of 5°≤ 2θ ≤ 80°, whereas the small-angle X-ray scattering was recording at a scanning rate of 2θ = 1° per min, between 2° ≤ 2θ ≤ 10°. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C on Quantachrome (Version 3.0, U.S.A). The catalysts were degassed at 300 °C for 6 h before physisorption to remove unwanted moisture/gases from the pores. The specific surface area of the catalyst has been calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method at the relative pressure range of 0.05−0.30. The pore size distribution analyzed from the adsorption isotherms using the standard Barrett-Joyner-Haleda (BJH) method. Internal morphology of synthesized catalyst was studied using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) with Tecnai G2 20 S-Twin (FEI, Netherlands). Before the TEM analysis, the samples were dispersed in ethanol and deposited on 300 mesh carbon-coated copper grids. The basic strength and basicity of the synthesized catalyst have been determined using the Hammett indicators and acid-base titration [12]. The indicators used were of phenolphthalein (H_ = 9.3), 2,4-dinitroaniline (H_ = 15) and 4-nitroaniline (H_ = 18.4). The typical procedure of the Hammett titration, three hundred milligram of the catalyst samples, was mixed with ten milliliters of methanol containing one milliliter of the Hammett indicator. The resultant solution mixed vigorously and kept ideally for 2 h to reach equilibrium. The color change of the solution was monitored with the naked eye. The catalyst's relative base strength labeled as stronger if any color change occurs with a particular strength of the indicator; otherwise, the catalyst designated as weaker than an indicator. The acid-base titration method was adopted to quantify the basic amount of the catalyst. The color change solution was titrated with 0.02 M benzoic acid in methanol, based on the amount of acid consumed to neutralize the solid samples were quantified as total basic sites. The thermal stability of the synthesized catalyst has been investigated on PerkinElmer STA-6000 (Massachusetts, USA) thermogravimetric analysis. Typically, 10 mg of sample was placed in an alumina crucible, and the temperature was raised from ambient to 600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 (10 mL/min) atmosphere. Active metal coordination with support has been analyzed on Scienta Omicron spectrometer using Al-Kα source. The samples were placed on a copper surface at room temperature under an ultrahigh vacuum prior to analysis. 1H NMR spectra of the product mixture was recorded on a Delta2_NMR 400 MHz spectrometer employing CDCl3 as a solvent. 2.4 Transesterification of glycerol and dimethyl carbonate The transesterification reaction of glycerol with DMC was conducted in a 100 mL three-necked round-bottom glass reactor attached to a thermometer and a reflux condenser. The reactor was placed in an oil bath over the magnetic stirrer (5 MLHS Plus, REMI, India). A required quantity of different molar ratios of DMC to glycerol has been charged in the reactor and allowed to raise the reaction temperature to its desired temperature at a constant stirring speed of 1000 rpm. After that, the catalyst has been charged in the reaction mixture to initiate the reaction. At different time intervals, reaction mixture was withdrawn, centrifuged at 9000 rpm and filtered to separate the catalyst. The glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield were determined quantitatively from gas chromatography (Trace 1310, ThermoFisher Scientific, USA) with a capillary column (Quadrex, 007−5, Connecticut, US; 30 m X 0.25 mm X 0.25 μm) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID). 1 μL of the filtered sample was mixed with 1 mL of pyridine and injected to split/splitless injector. The injector and detector temperatures were maintained at 290 °C and 320 °C, respectively. All the calculations were done by assuming the glycerol as a limiting reagent and are represented in the Eqs. (1–4). It was found that 7 % of potassium loaded TUD-1 provided the maximum yield of glycerol carbonate. Hence the characterization studies were focused on 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 along with bare TUD-1 to confirm its physio-chemical properties. Fig. 1 (a) shows the FTIR spectra of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, and regenerated catalyst. The band at 456.08 cm−1 might be due to the stretching frequency of the SiO bond of the silica ring structure [13]. A peak at 810 cm−1 may be attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si. The band at 1087.33 cm−1 and a shoulder band near 1200 cm−1 may be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si. A peak near 1634 cm−1 can be allotted to surface silanol group or bending vibration of the water molecule in the tetrahedral framework of SiO2 [14]. The presence of a band at 3439 cm−1 may be allocated to surface silanol group (SiOH) or water molecule attached to the surface of the catalyst. As can be seen, no peaks of potassium oxide or any potassium entity was observed in all the spectra that indicate the complete dispersion of potassium species in the mesoporous framework of TUD-1. However, in the regenerated spectrum of 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, the hydroxyl peak at 3410 cm−1 broadened due to the accumulation of remained glycerol molecule in the pores of catalyst [15]. Additionally, a more pronounced peak at 2955 cm−1, 2313 cm−1, 644.27 cm-1 were observed owing to carbon stretching due to the presence of organic components in the regenerated catalyst [16]. The thermal stability of TUD-1 and 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 was examined as a function of temperature under the nitrogen atmosphere by thermo-gravimetric analysis in Fig. 1(b). Two weight-loss zones have been observed in bare TUD-1. The first weight loss zone might be due to the loss of water vapors from the pores of the three-dimensional mesoporous silica structure. The second weight loss zone may be due to the decomposition of un-decomposed surfactant molecules. The total weight loss of ∼25 % through two zones was observed, indicating that the prepared catalyst possess excellent thermal stability up to 600 °C [17]. Further, the TGA profile of 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 was observed similar weight loss of ∼22 %. However, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, only one major weight loss zone, was observed due to the decomposition of potassium nitrate and surfactant molecules from 150 to 250 °C [18]. The wide-angle powder XRD pattern of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, and regenerated 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 is depicted in Fig. 2 (a). All samples exhibited a broad hump 2θ from 10−40º, it confirmed that prepared catalyst possess amorphous silica structure (Fig. 2(a)) [19]. Besides, a small peak 2θ at 31° suggests the formation of potassium oxide in the framework of the TUD-1 structure [20]. However, except for a small peak, no significant peaks were found corresponding to potassium in the framework of TUD-1, it indicating the good dispersion of potassium species in the mesoporous structure of silica. In addition, the XRD pattern of 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 demonstrate a similar structure, indicating that both synthesis techniques are potential. However, in regenerated 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, peak corresponding to potassium species was disappeared ascribed to the partial conversion of oxides into the corresponding hydroxide (KOH) during transesterification reaction. The small-angle XRD pattern of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, and regenerated 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 illustrated in Fig. 2(b). The TUD-1 samples exhibited a sharp peak 2θ at 0.9° which is indicating wormhole-like or a disordered mesoporous structure. It is good agreement with reported literature on TUD-1 [21]. However, a very slight shift of diffraction peak 2θ from 0.9° to 0.98° for potassium metal incorporated TUD-1 (7% Cal/K-TUD-1, 7% Ext/K-TUD-1), may be due to incorporation of non-framework potassium species in the mesoporous framework of TUD-1 [22]. It is a well-known fact that active species incorporation could affect the final textural properties of mesoporous silica [21]. In addition, the XRD diffraction of regenerated 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 catalyst exhibited weaker and broader peak, might be due to either destruction of mesopores because of chemical reaction in the pores or accumulation of glycerol molecule in the pores of TUD-1. The information about the elemental state on the surface of the catalyst can be obtained through XPS. The deconvoluted spectra of C 1s, O 1s, Si 2p, K 2p of TUD-1, and 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 depicted in Fig. 3 . A clear doublet was perceived in XPS spectra (Fig. 3(a)) of C 1s of TUD-1, and it was deconvoluted in three characteristic peaks, at 284.17 eV, 285.69 eV, and 286.51 eV due to presence of carbon bond CC,CO, and CO bond, respectively [23,24]. The minor decrease in relative intensity of CC and CO has observed in potassium loaded TUD-1; this may be due to the interaction of potassium with carbon and oxygen; the peak intensity was decreased (Fig. 3(b)). Additionally, CO group of bare TUD-1 was changed to the carboxyl group, CO (287.05 eV) that further clarifies the interaction of potassium species with the carbon group of TUD-1 [25]. The deconvoluted XPS spectra of O 1s of TUD-1 and 7% K-TUD-1 is presented in Fig. 3(c and d). The spectra of O 1s was deconvoluted in two peaks, that is, 531.98 eV (CO) and 532.98 eV(CO). After the addition of potassium, it was observed that the intensity of CO increased, which ascribed to the interaction of oxygen group with potassium entities [20,21]. Further, Si 2p of TUD-1 and 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 was deconvoluted (Fig. 3(e) and (f)), signals of Si 2p3/2 (102.46 eV), Si 2p1/2 (103.15 eV) indicate the presence of silicon dioxide or Si4+ species in the framework of TUD-1. The peak at 104.02 eV was assigned to OSiO bond present on the surface of bare TUD-1. The relative intensity of OSiO bond reduced in 7% Cal/K-TUD-1. This might be responsible for the interaction of silica with potassium species. Fig. 3g shows the K 2p spectra of 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 catalyst. Two adjacent peaks at 293.27 eV and 296.03 eV formed due to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, assigned to the KO group. The KO spectrum might be due to K–O-Si linkage, and responsible for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate [26]. TEM images of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 is shown in Fig. 4 . It revealed that TUD-1 possesses three-dimensional sponge-like mesoporous structure at higher magnification [27]. At lower magnification, all samples i.e. TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 exhibited disordered foam type structure. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 shown in Fig. 5 (a and b). The hysteresis loop of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 illustrate the characteristic feature of type IV adsorption isotherm, indicating the mesoporous framework of bare TUD-1 material can be well-retained after incorporation of potassium species. Furthermore, bare TUD-1 resembles H1 type hysteresis loop at a relative pressure p/po = 0.6–1.0 due to capillary condensation of mesopores such material resembles wormhole pore architectures [18,28]. Whereas, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 exhibited an H2 type hysteresis loop indicating the ink-bottle type of pores structure due to active metal incorporation. The surface area of TUD-1 was 631 m2/g and decreased slightly with the incorporation of active metal species, 430 m2/g and 372 m2/g for 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, respectively. A similar decreasing trend has been observed for corresponding pore volume 0.525 cc/g, 0.324 cc/g, and 0.284 cc/g of TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, respectively. The reduction in surface area and pore volume may be due to the incorporation/interaction of active metal species on the support of TUD-1 [26,27]. However, the average pore diameter was observed 1.698 nm, 2.579 nm, and 2.580 nm for TUD-1, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, and 7% Ext/K-TUD-1, respectively. This may be due to the accumulation of potassium species on pore walls leads to high pore diameter [28,29]. The calcined catalyst (7% Cal/K-TUD-1) possesses slightly high surface area, pore volume, and low pore diameter when compared with the solvent extraction catalyst (7% Ext/K-TUD-1). The observed trend might be due to incomplete templates removal through solvent extraction processes [30]. The average pore diameter of TUD-1, Cal/K-TUD-1, and Ext/K-TUD-1 shows the uniform distribution of pores with maximum pores lying up to 10 nm that corresponds to the presence of cylindrical mesopores along with some micro-porous particles (Fig. 5(b)). 3.2 Screening of catalyst Catalytic transesterification of glycerol with DMC over 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 has been investigated with an aim to maximize the glycerol carbonate yield and selectivity, glycerol conversion, and TOF by varying influencing parameters such as active metal loading on support, catalyst dose, DMC to glycerol molar ratio, reaction temperature and time. Most of the studies (Fig. 6 (a–f)), it was found that selectivity of glycerol carbonate has not fluctuated significant quantity, it indicated that the synthesized catalyst has high selectivity for the conversion of glycerol into glycerol carbonate without the formation of side products. Besides, TOF also almost followed a similar trend, like the yield of glycerol carbonate. 3.2.1 Effect of active metal loading amount Effect of active metal loading (Cal/K-TUD-1) with the basicity of the catalyst have been evaluated for the transesterification reaction of glycerol with DMC and obtained results depicted in Table 1 and Fig. 6(a). Before catalytic activity evaluation, experiments were conducted in the absence of catalyst for the transesterification of glycerol with DMC, and it observed no significant glycerol carbonate formation. In addition, the catalytic activity of bare TUD-1 also evaluated, results revealed that relatively less yield and conversion of glycerol carbonate and glycerol, respectively. This might be due to insufficient desired basicity to accelerate the reaction rate (shown in Table 1). The transesterification activity of active metal incorporated TUD-1 is shown in Fig. 6a. The conversion of glycerol and yield of glycerol carbonate was increased with an increase of active potassium loading on TUD-1 (2% Cal/K-TUD-1 < 5% Cal/K-TUD-1 < 7% Cal/K-TUD-1). The positive trend may be due to an increase of basicity and basic-strength of the catalyst with the incorporation of active metal on TUD-1 [31]. However, further, an increase of active metal loading (10 % Cal/K-TUD-1) declining trend was observed on glycerol conversion and yield of glycerol carbonate. In spite of an increase of basicity and basic strengths of 10 % Cal/K-TUD-1, the catalytic activity was decreased, this may be due to blockage of active pores with excessive loading of active metal on TUD-1 framework. Based on these findings, 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 was chosen as the best catalyst to conduct further study. 3.3 Effect of the operating variables on the transesterification reaction 3.3.1 Effect of catalyst dosage The available active site of the catalyst strongly influences the energy barrier and speed up the transesterification reaction of glycerol. Different experiment were conducted by varying the catalyst dose from 1 wt.% to 8 wt.% based on glycerol mass to investigate the outcome of transesterification reaction of glycerol shown in Fig. 6(b). When the catalyst dose increased from 1 wt.% to 6 wt.% the glycerol carbonate yield (from 6.66 % to 53.54 %), glycerol conversion (6.75 % to 56.17 %) and TOF (0.52 to 4.33 h−1) increases to the maximum. Further, increase of catalyst dose (8 wt.% of glycerol mass), the glycerol conversion, glycerol carbonate yield and TOF showed a drop trend. This can be interpreted by the following reasons. At lower catalyst dose (< 6 wt.%), it may not provide sufficient number of active sites to achieve a high yield and conversion. In the other side, the abundant active sites (8 wt.% of catalyst) during the reaction may only accelerate the reaction rate rapidly with less time but reaction equilibrium was not changed [32]. 3.3.2 Effect of DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio plays a significant role on the diffusivity of reactants through the pores of catalyst, thereby influencing the yield of glycerol carbonate [33]. The DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio was varied from 1 to 7, at a constant catalyst dose of 6 wt.%, reaction temperature of 80 °C, and reaction time of 2 h (Fig. 6(c)). With an increase in molar ratio from 1 to 5, displayed the increase of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield from 23.40 % to 64.42 % and 22.00 % to 62.00 %, respectively was perceived. The transesterification reaction of glycerol with DMC is reversible, to shift the equilibriums of the reaction towards glycerol carbonate formation high molar ratio of DMC and glycerol reactant molecules need to maintain. However, a further increase of the DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio beyond 5 declining trend of yield and conversion was observed. At a higher molar ratio of DMC to glycerol results, dilution of reactant molecule glycerol takes place which resulted in the drop of contact rate between reactant molecules and active sites [32]. Therefore, the DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio of 5 was chosen as an optimized molar ratio to perform subsequent studies. 3.3.3 Effect of reaction temperature Reaction temperature plays a pivotal role in yield and conversion during catalytic transesterification of glycerol with DMC. Therefore, the effect of reaction temperature on glycerol conversion, glycerol carbonate yield, and TOF was studied ranging from 70 °C to 100 °C using a DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio of 5 and catalyst dosage of 6 wt.% in 2 h of reaction time throughout the reaction regime and the results presented in Fig. 6(d). The transesterification exhibited a gradual increase of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield from 50 °C to 90 °C. The maximum glycerol carbonate yield of 71 %, glycerol conversion of 74 % and TOF of 5.74 h−1 at a reaction temperature of 90 °C was observed. This may be due to the acceleration of molecules movement results in high collusion, as well as enhancement of miscibility of glycerol with DMC, results in gradual increment trend. The reaction temperature further increases of above 90 °C; the yield and conversion were not increased significantly. Though, a slight decrease in the yield of glycerol carbonate was observed at 100 °C owing to the formation of by-products at higher temperatures with methanol in the reaction mixture. 3.3.4 Effect of reaction time The influence of reaction time on glycerol carbonate yield and glycerol conversion was investigated by varying the reaction time from 0.5 h to 3 h at optimized reaction conditions (Fig. 6(e)). The yield of glycerol carbonate and conversion of glycerol increased from 32.00 % to 91.53 % and 32.67 % to 98.00 %, respectively with the increase in reaction time from 0.5 h to 3 h. However, the selectivity of glycerol carbonate decreased when the reaction was prolonged for 3 h. It was believed that the catalyst would catalyze the transesterification of glycerol predominately, at the same time it would also aid in decarbonylation of glycerol carbonate molecule. Once the formation of glycerol carbonate reached equilibrium, the decomposition of glycerol carbonate molecule into by-product becomes predominant. Thus in the present study, transesterification reaction was proceeded for 2.5 h. In order to identify the by-product of the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate, NMR analysis of the product mixture under optimized condition was carried out. From the NMR spectra, signals of glycidol was found, and the possible by-product of the reaction shown in Fig. 7. Further, the signals of glycidol have appeared in NMR analysis may be due to decarboxylation of glycerol carbonate on the excess site available on the surface of catalyst. Glycidol: 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz), δ (ppm), 4.713 (1H,-OH), 3.009 (1H, -CH2-CH-), 2.669 (1H, -CH2-CH-), 3.630, 3.344 (2H, -O-CH2) [34]. 3.4 Effective template removal technique Two synthesis methods i.e., calcination and solvent extraction, have been adopted for templates removal in the mesoporous framework of silica. Both materials (7% Ext/K-TUD-1 and 7% Cal/K-TUD-1) catalytic activity were assessed in transesterification of glycerol with DMC under optimized conditions i.e., catalyst dose of 6 wt.%, DMC to glycerol molar ratio of 5, reaction temperature of 90 °C in 2.5 h reaction time. Experimental results revealed that 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 marked the higher catalytic activity on glycerol conversion of 98.41 % and glycerol carbonate yield of 91.53 %. On the other side, 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 marked the slightly lower catalytic activity on glycerol conversion of 90.23 % and glycerol carbonate yield of 84.58 %. The observed trend may be due to many reasons: (i) The 7% Ext/K-TUD-1 possess slightly lower BET surface area, pore volume when compared with 7% Cal/K-TUD-1, due to this reason the low yield was observed on 7% Ext/K-TUD-1. (ii) Through the calcination technique, the active metal species might be converted into its oxide states, which may enhance desired basic sites. Through the solvent technique, templates may remove effective, but enhancement of basic sites may not possible. 3.5 Reaction mechanism For the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate, a highly active basic site is required to activate the primary hydroxyl group of glycerol. The present work speculated that the KOSi bond (XPS study) activates the hydroxyl group of glycerol and carbonyl group of DMC. The plausible reaction mechanism depicted in Scheme 1 , where ‘A’ represents the acid site (Kn+) whereas ‘B’ represents the basic site (O2-). The weak conjugate base abstracts a proton from the primary hydroxyl group of a glycerol molecule and form glyceroxide anion. The formed glyceroxide anion react with carbonyl carbon of DMC forms the methyl glycerate carbonate and releases one molecule of methanol. Finally, the methyl glycerate carbonate undergoes cyclization by reacting with the secondary hydroxyl group of glycerol with carbonyl carbon of DMC and yield glycerol carbonate molecule and methanol species. 3.6 Reusability study The reusability study considered to be an essential study to assess industrial-scaleup. The reusability study of 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 was conducted by separating the catalyst from the product mixture through centrifugation, followed by its washing with methanol. Then the washed catalyst was dried at 120 °C for 12 h in a hot air oven and further used for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate. A similar procedure was adopted after each subsequent reuse of catalyst, and the activity of the catalyst was evaluated under optimized conditions. It was observed that the glycerol carbonate yield and glycerol conversion reduced significantly from 91.53 % to 74.72 % and 98.41 % to 83.11 %, respectively, after the fourth cycle of reusability (Fig. 6(f)). However, an insignificant decrease (∼3 %) in the selectivity of glycerol carbonate was perceived after the fourth reuse of catalyst. To understand the reason behind the loss in activity of catalyst, the catalyst was recovered from the product mixture and examined with FTIR and XRD techniques (Described in section 3.1). From the FTIR and XRD results, it is obvious that the leaching of potassium species from the pores of the catalyst may be possible, which leads to a decrease in the activity of the catalyst. The other possible reason may be the blockage of catalyst pores with un-reacted reactant molecules, leading to the low conversion and yield [32]. Further, this has been confirmed with SAXS results of the regenerated catalyst; that regenerated catalyst may not exhibit the mesoporous nature which indicates the pore may be filled with organic compounds. 3.7 Kinetic study In the present manuscript, the catalytic transesterification reaction proceeds in three major steps, i.e., Step 1: adsorption of reactant molecules (glycerol and DMC) on the active sites of catalyst; In the second step surface reaction between glycerol and DMC in which hydroxyl group of glycerol reacts with activated carbonyl carbon of DMC forming an intermediate complex [1-(o-methoxy-carbonyl)] with generation of methanol molecule. The formed complex undergoes cyclization and to form glycerol carbonate and methanol molecule; in the last step, desorption of glycerol carbonate and methanol molecules from the catalyst pores into bulk phase and catalyst regenerated for further participation in the catalytic reaction. The probable dual-site mechanism was defined by Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) kinetic model to explain the above reaction mechanism. The experimental results of glycerol and glycerol carbonate concentration at different temperatures (70−100 °C) data were used in the objective function (Eq. 29). The ‘Fmincon’ optimization tool using stiff integrators-ODE15 s from the MATLAB utilized to solve the obtained ordinary differential equation during the execution. The values of reaction rate constants were constrained within positive real numbers. The experimental and simulated results at different temperatures were presented in Fig. 8 . The rate constant was evaluated based on the principle that the sum of square error (SSE), root mean square error (RMSE) and chi-square (χ2) should tend to zero (Eq. 31, 32 and 33), and the coefficient of determination should tend to one (Eq. 30) [36]. The values of sum of square error (SSE), root mean square error (RMSE), chi-square (χ2) and the coefficient of determination was used as a criteria to validate the fit of the model. Table 2 summarizes the statistical parameters of the kinetic model. The small value of SSE, RMSE, χ2, and, relatively close to one of R2 i.e. larger than 0.9082 suggest that the model was good fit with experimental data. Table 3 represents the equilibrium constants and apparent reaction rate constant evaluated at different temperatures (70−100 °C). It was seen that the values of apparent reaction rate constants increased with an increase of reaction temperature. The acquired values of apparent rate constants were used to evaluate the activation energy of the system using the Arrhenius equation (shown in Table 3), and the activation energy of 39.64 kJ/mol was calculated. Various researchers worked on the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate, and determined activation energy for their systems such as, Devi et al. [10] calculated activation energy of 39.2 kJ/mol using Ti/SBA-15 catalyst. Similarly, Esteban et al. [37] determined activation energy of 28.4 ± 1.5 kJ/mol using potassium methoxide catalyst. Yadav and Chandan [38] reported the activation energies of 52.50 kJ/mol employing calcined hydrotalcite supported hexagonal silica catalyst. The results reported in the literature are in accordance with the activation energy calculated in present study. 3.8 Comparison of catalytic activity of K-TUD-1 with other potassium based catalyst Few studies have been reported in the literature that employs active potassium metal-based catalysts for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate. Du et al. [39] investigated the K2CO3/MgO catalytic activity for glycerol carbonate synthesis from glycerol. The results concluded that almost 100 % selectivity of glycerol carbonate and 99 % glycerol conversion was achieved at 80 °C in 2 h using the K2CO3/MgO catalyst. However, the reusability study revealed that a sharp decline in catalytic activity, only 70 % yield was observed in the fifth reused catalyst. Bai et al. [40] studied the catalytic activity of KF/HAP catalysts for glycerol carbonate synthesis. The 15 wt.% KF/HAP catalyst showed stable catalytic activity for up to four cycles with 97 % glycerol conversion and 99.5 % glycerol carbonate selectivity, due to its stable porous support material i.e. HAP. However, during reusability, 111 ppm/g of KF was leached into the product mixture; the toxic nature of KF substance is a major constrain to this process. In the present study, 7% potassium incorporated stable three-dimensional mesoporous structure was prepared using silica material for the easy access of glycerol molecule into catalyst pores and active sites. Therefore, it could be concluded that 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 would be a good candidate for the transesterification of glycerol into glycerol carbonate. 4 Conclusion The potassium incorporated three-dimensional mesoporous silica is disclosed as a promising catalyst for the practical application of glycerol carbonate synthesis. The small-angle X-ray scattering justifies the formation of a well-ordered mesoporous structure. 7% Cal/K-TUD-1 showed a maximum yield of glycerol carbonate 91.53 % and glycerol conversion of 98 % at the reaction temperature of 90 °C, DMC-to-glycerol molar ratio of 5, and catalyst dosage of 6 wt.% (concerning glycerol mass) in 2.5 h of reaction time. The catalyst activation through calcination processes showed more significant catalytic activity as compared with solvent extraction processes. The kinetic model was solved using the ODE 15 s solver available in MATLAB. The activation energy for the transesterification reaction was found to be 39.64 kJ/mol. The synthesized can be utilized commercially for the valorization of glycerol obtained from the biodiesel into glycerol carbonate. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, a series of potassium (K) incorporated three-dimensional mesoporous silica material (K/TUD-1) has been synthesized for the one-pot synthesis of glycerol carbonate through transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The synthesized catalyst (K/TUD-1) has been characterized to confirm porosity by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Small-angle XRD revealed that TUD-1 is mesostructure in nature. Morphology study revealed that TUD-1 exhibited a 3D structure without any agglomeration. The surface area of bare TUD-1 significantly declined with the incorporation of active metal from 632 m2/g to 430 m2/g. However, the basicity of K/TUD-1 improved, which is a highly desired property for the transesterification reaction. Batch experimental results have been concluded that 7% K/TUD-1 has better catalytic activity for the conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate. Further investigation has been conducted on the influence of reaction parameters such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst dosage, and DMC/glycerol molar ratio. Under optimized conditions the maximum glycerol carbonate yield (∼91.50 %) was observed with catalyst dose of 6 wt.% (of glycerol mass), DMC/glycerol molar ratio of 5, reaction temperature of 90 °C in 2.5 h. Further, catalyst feasibility was also conducted at optimized conditions, and it sustains activity up to 4 cycles. The kinetics of the reaction was studied using the ODE 15 s solver in MATLAB.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol using three-dimensional mesoporous silicates of K/TUD-1 under environmentally benign conditions
